animations.brief:
Animations in SplashKit can be used to move between cells in
bitmaps and sprites. Each animation generates a number sequence
that can then be used when drawing bitmaps.

functions.name: animation_count
functions.description: Returns the number of `animation`s within an `animation_script`.

return.description: Returns an `int` equal to the total number of animations in the script.

script.description: The `animation_script` to count the animations in.

functions.name: animation_current_cell
functions.description:
Returns the current cell (the part of the image or sprite) of this
animation. This can be used to animate an image or sprite.

return.description: Returns the current cell of the animation passed to the method.

anim.description: The `animation` to return the cell of.

functions.name: animation_current_vector
functions.description: Returns the `vector_2d` assigned to the current frame in the animation.

return.description: Returns the `vector_2d` assigned to the current frame in the animation.

anim.description: The animation to check the vector of.

functions.name: animation_ended
functions.description: Checks if an `animation` has ended.

return.description: Returns a `bool` denoting whether the `animation` has ended.

functions.name: animation_entered_frame
functions.description:
Returns true if the `animation` entered a new frame on its last update.
This can be used to trigger actions on frames within an animation.

return.description: Returns a `bool` denoting whether the `animation` has ended.

functions.name: animation_frame_time
functions.description:
Returns the amount of time spent in the current frame. When this
exceeds the frames duration the animation moves to the next frame.

return.description: Returns the amount of time spent in the current frame as a `float`.

functions.name: animation_index
functions.description:
Searches an `animation_script` for an `animation` and returns its
index.

return.description: Returns the index of the `animation` in the `animation_script`

script.description: The `animation_script` to look for the `animation` in.

name.description: The name of the `animation` to look for.

csharp: public static int SplashKit.AnimationIndex(AnimationScript script, string name);
pascal: function AnimationIndex(script: AnimationScript; const name: String): Integer

functions.name: animation_name
functions.description: Searches an `animation_script` for an animation and returns its name.

return.description: Returns the name of the `animation` in the `animation_script`.

functions.name: animation_script_name
functions.description: Retuns the name of an `animation_script`.

return.description: Returns a `string` that is the name of the animation script passed to the method.

script.description: The `animation_script` to return the name of.

functions.name: animation_script_named
functions.description:
Loads and returns a `animation_script`. The supplied filename is
used to locate the `animation_script` to load. The supplied name
indicates the name to use to refer to this in SplashKit. The
`animation_script` can then be retrieved by passing this name to
the animation_script_named method.

return.description: Returns the newly loaded `animation_script`.

name.description: Indicates the name used to locate the animation_script to load

functions.name: assign_animation
functions.description:
Setup an `animation` to follow the script from an indicated name.
This will switch the animation to use the supplied script.
It locates the name of the animation with the animation script and
sets the `anim` to start at that point in the script.

name.description: The name of the `animation` to be assigned.

with_sound.description: Denotes whether the `animation` should play audio.

functions.description: Disposes of the resources used in the animation.

functions.name: free_animation_script
functions.description:
Frees loaded animation frames data. Use this when you will no
longer be using the animation for any purpose, including within
sprite.

functions.name: free_animation_script
functions.description:
Frees loaded `animation_script` data. Use this when you will no

pascal: function HasAnimationNamed(script: AnimationScript; const name: String): Boolean

functions.description:
Determines if SplashKit has animation frames loaded for the
supplied name. This checks against all loaded animation frames,
those loaded without a name are assigned the filename as a default.

return.description: Returns the `bool` that denotes if the animation has the `animation_script`

functions.name: update_animation
functions.description:
Updates the animation, updating the time spent and possibly moving to
a new frame in the animation. This may play a sound effect if the new
frame triggers a sound.

with_sound.description: Denotes whether the `animation` should play audio.

audio.brief: SplashKit Audio allows you to load and play music and sound effects.
audio.description:
SplashKit's audio library allows you to easily load and play music and
sound effects within your programs. To get started with audio the first
thing you need to do is load a sound effect or music file. You can do this
by calling the `load_sound_effect(string name)` function to the
`load_music(string name)` function.

functions.name: audio_ready
functions.description:
Checks if SplashKit audio currently ready to be used.

Should this return `false`, you may want to use `open_audio`
to enable audio.

return.description: Returns `true` if the audio has been initalised.

functions.name: close_audio
functions.description: Turns off audio, stopping all current sounds effects and music.

functions.name: open_audio
functions.description: Starts the SplashKit audio system working.

functions.name: fade_music_in
functions.description: Fades music file matching the name to full volume over a specified number of milliseconds

name.description: The name of the `music` file to play.

ms.description: How many milliseconds it takes to fade the `music` to full volume

csharp: public static void SplashKit.FadeMusicIn(string name, int ms);
pascal: procedure FadeMusicIn(const name: String; ms: Integer)

functions.name: fade_music_in
functions.description:
Fades music file matching the name to full volume over a specified number of milliseconds
and loops a specified number of times

name.description: The name of the `music` file to play.

times.description: Controls the number of times the music is played.

ms.description: How many milliseconds it takes to fade the `music` to full volume

times.description: Controls the number of times the music is played.

functions.description: Fades music outover a specified number of milliseconds

functions.name: free_all_music
functions.description: Releases all of the music files that have been loaded.

functions.name: free_music
functions.description: Releases the SplashKit resources associated with music.

effect.description: The music file whose resources should be released.

functions.name: has_music
functions.description:
Determines if SplashKit has a music file loaded for the supplied name.
This checks against all music files loaded, those loaded without a name
are assigned the filename as a default. If this returns `false`, you may
want to use `load_music` to load in a specific sound effect and give
it the desired name.

return.description:
Returns `true` if there is a music file with the given `name` has
has been loaded.

name.description: The name to check if a music file is loaded.

functions.name: load_music
functions.description:
Loads and returns a music value. The supplied `filename` is used to
locate the music file to load. The supplied `name` indicates the
name to use to refer to this Music value. The `music` can then be
retrieved by passing this `name` to the `music_named` function.

return.description: A new music resource

name.description: The name of the resource for SplashKit

csharp: public static Music SplashKit.LoadMusic(string name, string filename);
pascal: function LoadMusic(const name: String; const filename: String): Music

functions.name: music_filename
functions.description: Returns the filename the of the music data

return.description: Returns a string with the filename of the `music` file.

functions.name: music_name
functions.description: Returns the name that SplashKit uses to refer to this music data

return.description: Returns a string with the name of the `music` that SplashKit refers to.

functions.name: music_named
functions.description: Retrieves a `music` that has been loaded into SplashKit.

return.description:
Returns the `music` that has been loaded with the specified
`name` using `load_music`.

name.description: The name of the music file to return.

functions.name: music_playing
functions.description: Checks whether music is currently playing.

return.description: Returns true or false value representing whether music is currently playing.

functions.name: music_valid
functions.description: Lets you test if music value is valid. This will return true when it is a valid music.

return.description: true when the music is valid.

functions.name: music_volume
functions.description: Returns the volume of the currently playing `music`.

return.description: Returns the percentage of the currently playing `music`.

functions.name: pause_music
functions.description: Pauses currently playing music - see resume_music to continue playing.

functions.name: play_music
functions.description: Plays the music file that matches the name once at full volume.

name.description: The name of the `music` to play.

functions.name: play_music
functions.description: Plays the music file that matches the name a specified number of times at full volume.

name.description: The name of the `music` to play.

Indicates the percentage of the original volume to play the
`music` at. This must be between `0` and `1`.

functions.name: resume_music
functions.description: Resumes currently paused music - see pause_music to pause playing music.

functions.name: set_music_volume
functions.description: Sets the volume of the currently playing `music`. Must be between 0 and 1, e.g. 0.1 is 10%.

volume.description:
Indicates the percentage of the original volume to play the

return.description: Returns whether the "sound_effect" is currently playing or not

functions.name: sound_effect_valid
functions.description: Lets you test if a sound effect is valid. This will return true when it is a valid sound effect.

return.description: true when the sound effect is valid.

functions.name: stop_sound_effect
functions.description: Stops the `sound_effect` that matches the name, if it is currently playing.

name.description: The name of the `sound_effect` to stop.

functions.name: stop_sound_effect
functions.description: Stops the `sound_effect` if it is currently playing

typedefs.name: music
typedefs.description:
The Music type is used to refer to music that can be
played by SplashKit. Music files are loaded with
`load_music`, played using `play_music`, and must be
released using `free_music`.

Unlike `sound_effect`s, there can only be one music track
playing at a time. Playing an new track will stop the currently
playing music and switch to the new track.

typedefs.name: sound_effect
typedefs.description:
The `sound_effect` type is used to refer to sound effects that can be
played by the SplashKit audio code. Sound effects are:


- loaded with `load_sound_effect`,

- played using `play_sound_effect`,

- and must be released using `delete_sound_effect` (to release a specific
sound effect) or `delete_all_sound_effects` (to release all loaded
sound effects).

SplashKit will mix the audio from multiple sound effects, making it
possible to play multiple `sound_effect`s, or even to play the one
`sound_effect` multiple times.

You can check if a `sound_effect` is currently playing using
`sound_effect_playing`.

To stop a `sound_effect` playing use `stop_sound_effect`. This will stop all
instances of this one sound effect from playing.

Use `music` for background music for your games.

camera.brief:
SplashKit camera functionality allows you to move a virtual camera
around in your world.
camera.description:
Splashkit camera functionality allows you to move a virtual camera around in
your world. This camera projects to the users window, allowing you to
draw things to the screen in your world coordinates.

functions.name: camera_position
functions.description:
Returns the position of the camera in game coordinates. This will be the
coordinate of the upper left corner of the screen.

return.description: The position of the camera as a point_2d.

functions.name: camera_x
functions.description:
Returns the x location of the camera in game coordinates. This represents
the left most x value shown on the screen, with the right of the screen
being at camera x + screen width.

return.description: The x location of the camera in game coordinates.

functions.name: camera_y
functions.description:
Returns the y location of the camera in game coordinates. This represents
the stop most y value shown on the screen, with bottom of screen being
at camera y + screen height.

return.description: The y location of the camera in game coordinates.

functions.name: center_camera_on
functions.description:
Set the camera view to be centered over the specific sprite. The offset
vector allows you to move the sprite from the direct center of the screen.

s.description: The sprite to track.

offset.description:
The amount to offset the camera, allowing you to position
the sprite away from the center of the screen.

csharp: public static void Camera.CenterOn(Sprite s, Vector2D offset);
public static void SplashKit.CenterCameraOn(Sprite s, Vector2D offset);
pascal: procedure CenterCameraOn(s: Sprite; const offset: Vector2D)

functions.name: center_camera_on
functions.description:
Set the camera view to be centered over the specific sprite. The offset
vector allows you to move the sprite from the direct center of the screen.

s.description: The sprite to track.

offset_x.description:
An additional offset added to the camera, allowing you to
position the sprite offset from the center of the screen.

offset_y.description:
An additional offset added to the camera, allowing you to
position the sprite offset from the center of the screen.

cpp: void center_camera_on(sprite s, double offset_x, double offset_y)
csharp: public static void Camera.CenterOn(Sprite s, double offsetX, double offsetY);
public static void SplashKit.CenterCameraOn(Sprite s, double offsetX, double offsetY);
pascal: procedure CenterCameraOn(s: Sprite; offsetX: Double; offsetY: Double)

functions.name: move_camera_by
functions.description:
Move the camera (offset its world x and y values) using the specified
vector. For example, if you move the camera by the same speed vector of
a sprite the camera will "track" (be locked on to) the sprite as it moves.

offset.description: The amount to move the camera.

functions.name: move_camera_by
functions.description:
Move the camera (offset its world x and y values) using the specified
dx (change in x) and dy (change in x) values.

dx.description: The amount to move the camera along the x axis.

dy.description: The amount to move the camera along the y axis.

csharp: public static void Camera.MoveBy(double dx, double dy);
public static void SplashKit.MoveCameraBy(double dx, double dy);

functions.name: move_camera_to
functions.description:
Move the camera view (screen top left) to a specified point in the world.
This will be the new top left corner of the screen.

pt.description: The new camera location

functions.name: move_camera_to
functions.description:
Move the camera view to a world location specified by the x and y values.
This will be the new top left corner of the screen.

x.description: The new camera x location

y.description: The new camera y location

csharp: public static void Camera.MoveTo(double x, double y);
public static void SplashKit.MoveCameraTo(double x, double y);

functions.name: point_in_window
functions.description: Tests if the point is in the window.

return.description: True if the point is on the screen.

pt.description: The point to check.

csharp: public static bool Camera.PointInWindow(Window wind, Point2D pt);
public static bool SplashKit.PointInWindow(Window wind, Point2D pt);
pascal: function PointInWindow(wind: Window; const pt: Point2D): Boolean

functions.name: point_on_screen
functions.description: Tests if the point is on the screen.

return.description: True if the point is on the screen.

pt.description: The point to check.

functions.name: rect_in_window
functions.description: Tests if the rectangle is within the bounds of the window.

return.description: True if any part of the rectangle is in the window.

rect.description: The rectangle to check.

csharp: public static bool Camera.RectInWindow(Window wind, Rectangle rect);
public static bool SplashKit.RectInWindow(Window wind, Rectangle rect);
pascal: function RectInWindow(wind: Window; const rect: Rectangle): Boolean

functions.name: rect_on_screen
functions.description: Tests if the rectangle is on the screen.

return.description: True if any part of the rectangle is on the screen.

rect.description: The rectangle to check.

functions.name: screen_center
functions.description: Returns the center of the screen in world coordinates.

return.description: The center of the screen in world coordinates.

functions.name: screen_rectangle
functions.description: Returns a rectangle that represents the dimensions of the window.

return.description: A rectangle representing the dimensions of the current window.

functions.name: set_camera_position
functions.description:
Change the position of the camera to a specified world coordinate. This
will then be the new top left most position of the screen within the world.

pos.description: The new location of the camera.

functions.name: set_camera_x
functions.description:
Change the X position of the camera to a specified world coordinate. This
will then be the new left most position of the screen within the world.

x.description: The new x coordinate for the camera

functions.name: set_camera_y
functions.description:
Change the Y position of the camera to a specified world coordinate. This
will then be the new top most position of the screen within the world.

y.description: The new y coordinate for the camera

functions.name: to_screen
functions.description: Convert the passed in world coordinates to screen coordinates.

return.description: A point that represents pt in screen coordinates.

pt.description: The point to convert - this should be in world coordinates.

functions.name: to_screen
functions.description: Convert the rectangle in world coordinates to screen coordinates.

return.description: A rectangle that represents rect in screen coordinates.

rect.description: The rectangle to convert - this should be in world coordinates.

functions.name: to_screen_x
functions.description:
Translate a world x value to the current screen x value which is based on
the camera position.

return.description: The x location of the world coordinate on the screen.

world_x.description: The value of the x coordinate to translate to screen.

functions.name: to_screen_y
functions.description: Translate a world y value to the current screen y value set by the camera.

return.description: The y location of the world coordinate on the screen.

world_y.description: The value of the y coordinate to translate to screen.

functions.name: to_world
functions.description: Converts the passed in point from screen coordinates to world coordinates.

return.description: The same point in world coordinates.

pt.description: The point in screen coordinates.

functions.name: to_world_x
functions.description: Translate a screen x value (based on the camera) to a world x value

return.description: The x location of the screen coordinate in the world.

screen_x.description:
The value of the x coordinate on screen to translate to
the world.

functions.name: to_world_y
functions.description: Translate a screen y value (based on the camera) to a world y value

return.description: The y location of the screen coordinate in the world.

screen_y.description:
The value of the y coordinate on screen to translate to
the world.

functions.name: vector_world_to_screen
functions.description: Returns a vector that can transform points from world to screen coordinates.

return.description:
A vector representing the distance and direction points need
to move to map from world to screen coordinates.

functions.name: window_area
functions.description:
Returns a rectangle that represents the dimensions of the window based
on the camera.

return.description: A rectangle representing the dimensions of the current window.

functions.name: hsb_color
functions.description: Returs a color from a combination of hue, saturation, and brightness.

return.description: The color from its hue, saturation and brightness.

hue.description: The hue of the color. Value must be between 0 and 1.

saturation.description: The saturation of that hue. Value must be between 0 and 1.

brightness.description: The brightness of the color. Value must be between 0 and 1.

cpp: color hsb_color(double hue, double saturation, double brightness)
csharp: public static Color Color.HSBColor(double hue, double saturation, double brightness);
public static Color SplashKit.HSBColor(double hue, double saturation, double brightness);
pascal: function HSBColor(hue: Double; saturation: Double; brightness: Double): Color

functions.name: hue_of
functions.description: Returns the hue of the supplied color.

return.description: The hue component of the color

functions.name: random_color
functions.description:
Creates and returns a random color where the color and its opacity are
random.

return.description: A random color

functions.name: random_rgb_color
functions.description:
Creates and returns a random color where the color is random, but the
opacity is set to the passed in value.

return.description: A random color with the set alpha

functions.name: red_of
functions.description: Returns the red of the supplied color.

return.description: The red component of the color

a value between 0 and 1.

functions.name: string_to_color
functions.description:
Returns a color for the passed in color string.
The format must be #, followed by the hex values
for the red, green, blue, and alpha components
of the color.

return.description: The color represented in the string

functions.name: circle_ray_intersection
functions.description:
Detects if a ray intersects a circle. If an intersection is found, the
`hit_point` and `hit_distance` are set to the point of intersection and the
distance from the ray's origin to the intersection point. If the ray's `origin`
is contained within the circle, `hit_point` is set to the `origin` and `hit_distance`
is set to 0. If no intersection is found, `hit_point` and `hit_distance` are not modified.

return.description: True if the ray intersects the circle, false otherwise

origin.description: The starting point of the ray

heading.description: The direction of the ray as a vector

circ.description: The circle to check for intersection

hit_point.description: The point to set to where the ray intersects the circle

hit_distance.description:
The double to set to the distance from the ray's origin to
the intersection point

cpp: bool circle_ray_intersection(const point_2d &origin, const vector_2d &heading, const circle &circ, point_2d &hit_point, double &hit_distance)
csharp: public static bool SplashKit.CircleRayIntersection(Point2D origin, Vector2D heading, Circle circ, ref Point2D hitPoint, ref double hitDistance);
pascal: function CircleRayIntersection(const origin: Point2D; const heading: Vector2D; const circ: Circle; var hitPoint: Point2D; var hitDistance: Double): Boolean

functions.name: circle_triangle_intersect
functions.description: Detects if a circle intersects with a triangle.

return.description: True if the circle and triangle intersect

csharp: public static bool SplashKit.CircleTriangleIntersect(Circle c, Triangle tri);
pascal: function CircleTriangleIntersect(const c: Circle; const tri: Triangle): Boolean

functions.name: circle_triangle_intersect
functions.description:
Detects if a circle intersects with a triangle. The closest point on the
triangle to the circle is assigned to p, even if the circle and triangle do not
intersect. If the centre of the circle is inside the triangle,
the point assigned to p is the centre of the circle.

return.description: True if the circle and triangle intersect

p.description: The point to set to the closest point on the triangle to the circle

cpp: bool circle_triangle_intersect(const circle &c, const triangle &tri, point_2d &p)
csharp: public static bool SplashKit.CircleTriangleIntersect(Circle c, Triangle tri, ref Point2D p);
pascal: function CircleTriangleIntersect(const c: Circle; const tri: Triangle; var p: Point2D): Boolean

Detects if two circles intersect. This can be used to detect collisions between

functions.name: circles_intersect
functions.description:
Detects if two circles intersect. This can be used to detect collisions between
bounding circles. The circle data is passed in as individual values.

return.description: true when the two circles intersect

c1_x.description: the x location of the first circle

c1_y.description: the y location of the first circle

c1_radius.description: the radius of the first circle

c2_x.description: the x location of the second circle

c2_y.description: the y location of the second circle

c2_radius.description: the radius of the second circle

pascal: function CirclesIntersect(c1X: Double; c1Y: Double; c1Radius: Double; c2X: Double; c2Y: Double; c2Radius: Double): Boolean

functions.name: closest_point_on_circle
functions.description:
Returns the closest point on a circle's circumference to
a given point. If the point is equal to the center of the circle,
the center point is returned.

return.description:
The point on `c`'s circumference that is closest to
`from_point`, or the center of the circle if the
point equals `c`'s center.

csharp: public static Point2D SplashKit.ClosestPointOnCircle(Point2D fromPt, Circle c);
pascal: function ClosestPointOnCircle(const fromPt: Point2D; const c: Circle): Point2D

functions.name: closest_point_on_line_from_circle
functions.description: Returns the closest point on a line to a circle.

return.description: The point that is closest to `c` on `l`

csharp: public static Point2D SplashKit.ClosestPointOnLineFromCircle(Circle c, Line l);
pascal: function ClosestPointOnLineFromCircle(const c: Circle; const l: Line): Point2D

functions.name: closest_point_on_rect_from_circle
functions.description: Returns the closest point on a rectangle's perimeter to a circle.

return.description: The point that is closest to `c` on `rect`'s perimeter

rect.description: The rectangle

csharp: public static Point2D SplashKit.ClosestPointOnRectFromCircle(Circle c, Rectangle rect);
pascal: function ClosestPointOnRectFromCircle(const c: Circle; const rect: Rectangle): Point2D

functions.name: closest_point_on_triangle_from_circle
functions.description:
Calculates the closest point on a triangle to a circle. If the circle and
triangle do not intersect, the closest point on the triangle to the circle
is returned. If the circle and triangle do intersect, the center of the
circle is returned.

return.description: The closest point on the triangle to the circle

csharp: public static Point2D SplashKit.ClosestPointOnTriangleFromCircle(Circle c, Triangle tri);
pascal: function ClosestPointOnTriangleFromCircle(const c: Circle; const tri: Triangle): Point2D

functions.name: distant_point_on_circle
functions.description: The furthest point on the circle to the given point.

return.description: The point on c that is furthest from `pt`

pt.description: The point to test from

c.description: The circle you want to get a point on its circumference

csharp: public static Point2D SplashKit.DistantPointOnCircle(Point2D pt, Circle c);
pascal: function DistantPointOnCircle(const pt: Point2D; const c: Circle): Point2D

functions.name: distant_point_on_circle_heading
functions.description:
Determines the opposite side of a circle given a collision point and a
heading.

return.description:
True when the `opposite_pt` is calculated, false when
the point would not collide with the circle when
heading as indicated.

pt.description: The point from which the test is being made

heading.description: The direction the point is heading

opposite_pt.description:
After the call, this is set to the point on the
opposite side of the circle from pt when it is
heading in the given direction.

functions.name: widest_points
functions.description:
Calculates the two points on a circles radius that lie along the given
vector. This represents the points on the circle when the vector is
placed at the circle's center point.

along.description: The vector representing the line along which the points lie.

pt1.description: After the call, this is set to one of the widest points

pt2.description: After the call, this is set to one of the widest points

functions.name: quad_ray_intersection
functions.description:
Detects if a ray intersects a quad. If an intersection is found, the
`hit_point` and `hit_distance` are set to the point of intersection and the
distance from the ray's origin to the intersection point. If the ray's `origin`
is contained within the quad, `hit_point` is set to the `origin` and `hit_distance`
is set to 0. If no intersection is found, `hit_point` and `hit_distance` are not modified.

return.description: True if the ray intersects the quad, false otherwise

origin.description: The starting point of the ray

heading.description: The direction of the ray as a vector

q.description: The quad to check for intersection

hit_point.description: The point to set to where the ray intersects the quad

hit_distance.description:
The double to set to the distance from the ray's origin to
the intersection point

cpp: bool quad_ray_intersection(const point_2d &origin, const vector_2d &heading, const quad &q, point_2d &hit_point, double &hit_distance)

pascal: function QuadRayIntersection(const origin: Point2D; const heading: Vector2D; const q: Quad; var hitPoint: Point2D; var hitDistance: Double): Boolean

functions.name: pop_clip
functions.description:
Remove the last clipping rectangle pushed to the window. This
will then apply the previously pushed clipping rectangle.

functions.name: pop_clip
functions.description:
Remove the last clipping rectangle pushed to the current window. This
will then apply the previously pushed clipping rectangle.

functions.name: pop_clip
functions.description:
Remove the last clipping rectangle pushed to the bitmap. This
will then apply the previously pushed clipping rectangle.

functions.name: push_clip
functions.description:
Add the clipping rectangle of a window and uses the intersect between
the new rectangle and previous clip.

When a clipping rectangle is provided, drawing operations will only
affect the area specified in the current clipping rectangle.

wnd.description: The window to add clipping to

csharp: public static void SplashKit.PushClip(Window wnd, Rectangle r);
pascal: procedure PushClip(wnd: Window; const r: Rectangle)

functions.name: push_clip
functions.description:
Add the clipping rectangle of a bitmap and uses the intersect between
the new rectangle and previous clip.

When a clipping rectangle is provided, drawing operations will only
affect the area specified in the current clipping rectangle.

bmp.description: The bitmap to add clipping to

csharp: public static void SplashKit.PushClip(Bitmap bmp, Rectangle r);
pascal: procedure PushClip(bmp: Bitmap; const r: Rectangle)

functions.name: push_clip
functions.description:
Push a clip rectangle to the current window. The resulting clipping
rectangle will be the intersection of the existing clipping rectangle
with the new rectangle provided in this call. This can be undone using
`pop_clip`.

When a clipping rectangle is provided, drawing operations will only
affect the area specified in the current clipping rectangle.

functions.name: reset_clip
functions.description:
Reset the clipping rectangle on a bitmap. This will clear all
of the clipping rectangles pushed to the bitmap.

bmp.description: The bitmap to clear the clipping rectangle

functions.name: reset_clip
functions.description:
Reset the clipping rectangle of the current window. This will clear all
of the clipping rectangles pushed to the current window.

functions.name: reset_clip
functions.description:
Reset the clipping rectangle on a window. This will clear all
of the clipping rectangles pushed to the window.

wnd.description: The window to clear the clipping rectangle

functions.name: set_clip
functions.description:
Set the clip rectangle of the current window. This will clear any
existing clipping rectangles pushed to the current window, and use the
supplied rectangle for clipping.

functions.name: set_clip
functions.description:
Set the clip rectangle of the bitmap. This will clear any existing
clipping rectangles pushed to the bitmap, and use the supplied rectangle
for clipping.

pascal: procedure SetClip(bmp: Bitmap; const r: Rectangle)

clipping rectangles pushed to the window, and use the supplied rectangle
for clipping.

functions.name: option_defaults

rotation or offset, not flipped, drawing whole images, with default
camera mechanisms and line width.

functions.name: option_with_bitmap_cell
functions.description:
When drawing the bitmap this will only draw the cell. To use this the bitmap
needs to have been provided with its cell details (see `bitmap_set_cell_details`).
This option overrides the animation or part drawing options.

return.description: A drawing option that will draw the selected cell.

cell.description: The cell to draw from the bitmap (-1 for entire bitmap)

functions.name: option_with_bitmap_cell
functions.description:
When drawing the bitmap this will only draw the cell. To use this the bitmap
needs to have been provided with its cell details (see `bitmap_set_cell_details`).
This option overrides the animation or part drawing options. This extends
the passed in drawing options with the cell details.

return.description: A drawing option that will draw the selected cell.

cell.description: The cell to draw from the bitmap (-1 for entire bitmap)

functions.name: load_bitmap
functions.description:
Loads and returns a bitmap. The supplied `filename` is used to
locate the Bitmap to load. The supplied `name` indicates the
name to use to refer to this Bitmap in SplashKit. The `bitmap` can then
be retrieved by passing this `name` to the `bitmap_named` function.

return.description: The loaded bitmap

name.description: The name of the bitmap resource in SplashKit

functions.name: setup_collision_mask
functions.description:
Sets up the collision mask for a bitmap. This enables collision detection between
this bitmap and other bitmaps or shapes.

This is automatically called when a bitmap is loaded, and only needs to be 
called on bitmaps created using `create_bitmap`, and when a bitmap is
changed by drawing onto the bitmap.

input.brief: Input handles user interaction and events such as keypresses.

functions.name: process_events
functions.description:
ProcessEvents allows SplashKit to react to user interactions. This
procedure checks the current keyboard and mouse states and should be
called once within your game loop to check user interaction.

Side Effects
- Reads user interaction events
- Updates keys down, text input, etc.

functions.name: quit_requested
functions.description:
Checks to see if the user has asked for the application to quit. This
value is updated by the `process_events` routine. Also see
`window_close_requested`.

return.description: True if the application has been requested to close.

functions.name: reset_quit
functions.description: Cancels a quit request, ensuring the quit requested will return false.

functions.name: any_key_pressed
functions.description:
Checks to see if any key has been pressed since the last time
`process_events` was called.

return.description: True if any key was pressed.

functions.name: deregister_callback_on_key_down
functions.description: Remove the registered callback from receiving events related to key down actions.

callback.description: The function to from from key down events

functions.name: deregister_callback_on_key_typed
functions.description: Remove the registered callback from receiving events related to key typed actions.

callback.description: The function to from from key typed events

functions.name: deregister_callback_on_key_up
functions.description: Remove the registered callback from receiving events related to key up actions.

callback.description: The function to from from key up events

functions.name: key_down
functions.description:
Returns true when the key requested is being held down. This is updated
as part of the `process_events` call. Use the key codes from `key_code`
to specify the key to be checked.

return.description: True if the key is currently held down

key.description: The key to check if it is down

functions.name: key_name
functions.description:
The `key_name` function returns a string name for a given `key_code`. For
example, `COMMA_KEY` returns the string 'Comma'. This function could be used
to display more meaningful key names for configuring game controls, etc.

return.description: The name of the key

key.description: The key to get the name of

functions.name: key_released
functions.description:
Returns true if the specified key was released since the last time
`process_events` was called. This occurs only once for the key that is
released and will not return true again until the key is pressed down and
released again.

return.description: True if the key was just released

key.description: The key to check if it was released

functions.name: key_typed
functions.description:
Returns true when the key requested is just pressed down. This is updated
as part of the `process_events` call. Use the key codes from `key_code`
to specify the key to be checked. this will only occur once for that key that is
pressed and will not return true again until the key is released and presssed down again

return.description: True if the key was just pressed down

key.description: The key to check if it was typed

functions.name: key_up
functions.description:
Returns false when the key requested is being held down. This is updated
as part of the `process_events` call. Use the key codes from `key_code`
to specify the key to be checked.

return.description: True if the key is currently up

key.description: The key to check if it is up

functions.name: register_callback_on_key_down
functions.description:
Register the passed in callback function to receive notification of key down
calls. This will be called in response to `process_events`, for each key that
the user presses down.

callback.description: The function to be called when a key is first pressed

functions.name: register_callback_on_key_typed
functions.description:
Register the passed in callback function to receive notification of key typed
calls. This will be called in response to `process_events`, when the user initially
presses a key down.

callback.description: The function to be called when a key is typed

functions.name: register_callback_on_key_up
functions.description:
Register the passed in callback function to receive notification of key up
calls. This will be called in response to `process_events`, for each key that
the user releases.

callback.description: The function to be called when a key is released

functions.name: hide_mouse
functions.description:
Tells the mouse cursor to hide (no longer visible) if it is currently
showing. Use `ShowMouse` to make the mouse cursor visible again.

functions.name: mouse_clicked
functions.description:
Returns true if the specified button was clicked since the last time
`process_events` was called.

return.description: True if the mouse button was clicked

functions.name: mouse_down
functions.description: Returns `true` if the specified button is currently pressed down.

return.description: True if the mouse button is down

functions.name: mouse_movement
functions.description:
Returns the amount of accumulated mouse movement, since the last time
`process_events` was called, as a `vector_2d`.

return.description: The movement of the mouse since the last process events

functions.name: mouse_position
functions.description: Returns the current window position of the mouse as a `Point2D`

return.description: The position of the mouse in the current window.

functions.name: mouse_position_vector
functions.description: Returns The current window position of the mouse as a `Vector`

return.description: The offset from the window origin to the mouse.

functions.name: mouse_shown
functions.description: Returns `true` if the mouse is currently visible, `false` if not.

return.description: True if the mouse is shown.

functions.name: mouse_up
functions.description: Returns `true` if the specified button is currently up.

return.description: True if the mouse button is up (i.e. not down)

functions.name: mouse_wheel_scroll
functions.description:
Returns the amount the mouse wheel was scrolled since the last call
to `process_events`. The result is a vector containing the x and y
amounts scrolled. Scroll left generates a negative x, scroll right a
positive x. Scroll backward is negative y, scroll forward positive y.
Note that on MacOS the directions may be inverted by OS settings.

return.description:
The distance and direction of the mouse scroll since the last
`process_events`

functions.name: mouse_x
functions.description: Returns the current x value of the mouse's position.

return.description:
The distance of the mouse from the left edge of the current
window location

functions.name: mouse_y
functions.description: Returns the current y value of the mouse's position.

return.description:
The distance of the mouse from the top edge of the current
window location

functions.name: move_mouse
functions.description: Moves the mouse cursor to the specified screen location.

x.description: The new x location of the mouse

y.description: The new y location of the mouse

csharp: public static void SplashKit.MoveMouse(double x, double y);

functions.name: move_mouse
functions.description: Moves the mouse cursor to the specified screen location.

point.description: The new location of the mouse

functions.name: show_mouse
functions.description:
Tells the mouse cursor to be visible if it was previously hidden with
by a `HideMouse` or `SetMouseVisible`(False) call.

functions.name: show_mouse
functions.description:
Used to explicitly set the mouse cursors visible state (if it is showing
in the window or not) based on the show parameter.

show.description: When true the mouse is shown, when false it is hidden

typedefs.name: key_callback
typedefs.description:
The `key_callback` is a function pointer used to register your code with SplashKit
or keyboard related events. See `register_callback_on_key_down`,
`register_callback_on_key_up`, and `register_callback_on_key_typed`

enums.name: key_code
enums.description:
These are the key codes you can use to check details of keyboard actions.
See `key_down`, `key_up`, `key_typed`, and `key_released` functions.
You can get a string representation of these keys using `key_name`.

RIGHT_ALT_KEY.description: The right alt or option key

LEFT_ALT_KEY.description: The left alt or option key

LEFT_SUPER_KEY.description: The left super (windows or command) key

RIGHT_SUPER_KEY.description: The right super (windows or command) key

enums.name: mouse_button
enums.description:
A mouse can have many different types of buttons. Most people know
about the simple Left and Right buttons, but there is also a Middle
button (sometimes part of a scoll wheel), and possible side buttons.

signatures.cpp: class mouse_button {NO_BUTTON = 0, LEFT_BUTTON = 0, MIDDLE_BUTTON = 0, RIGHT_BUTTON = 0, MOUSE_X1_BUTTON = 0, MOUSE_X2_BUTTON = 0};

interface.brief: SplashKit Interface provides functions to create user interfaces, with elements such as draggable panels, buttons and text boxes.
interface.description:
SplashKit`s interface library provides various functions for creating
panels, and drawing interface elements such as buttons, text boxes, and more

functions.name: add_column
functions.description:
Adds a column to the current layout with width `width`.

- Positive values of width just specify the width in pixels.
- 0 means use the default control width - not always a good choice.
- Negative values specify filling to the right _until_ `width + 1` pixels away from the edge.
- e.g -1 fills entirely to the right, while -20 leaves a 19 pixel gap on the right.

width.description: Width of the column in pixels

functions.name: add_column_relative
functions.description: Adds a column to the current layout with width `width` percentage of the container's width.

width.description: Percentage of the container's width (between 0 and 1)

functions.name: bitmap_button
functions.description:
Creates a button with a bitmap in it, and no label.
Returns whether the button was clicked.

return.description: Whether the button was clicked

bmp.description: The bitmap to show inside the button

functions.name: bitmap_button

functions.name: disable_interface
functions.description: Disables the interface temporarily. Elements created after this function will appear disabled and cannot be interacted with.

functions.name: draw_interface
functions.description:
Draws the user interface that all the previous calls (such as `start_panel`, `button`, etc) have created.

**Make sure to call this!** Without calling it, the interface won't be visible.

functions.name: enable_interface
functions.description: Re-enables the interface, reverses the effects of disabling the interface.

functions.name: end_popup

with the same name.

json.brief: SplashKit Json allows you to create and read JSON objects.
json.description:
Splashkit's JSON library allows you to easily create or read JSON objects and
manipulate them to/from a JSON string or from a file containing a JSON
string. Create a new JSON object with a call to `create_json()` and
read or write data to it by calling methods like
`json_add_string(json j, string key, string value)` and
`json_read_string(json j, string key)`.

functions.name: create_json
functions.description:
The empty `json` object returned can be filled with data and read by the
functions and procedures prefixed with `json_add_` and `json_read_`
functions.brief: Creates an empty `json` object.

return.description: Returns an empty `json` object.

functions.name: create_json
functions.description:
`string json_string` must be valid JSON.
The `json` object returned can be filled with data and read by the functions
and procedures prefixed with `json_add_` and `json_read_`
functions.brief: Creates a `json` object filled with JSON fields from `json_string`.

return.description: Returns a `json` object filled with data from the parameter `string`.

json_string.description: The JSON formatted `string` to be converted to a `json` object.

functions.name: free_all_json
functions.description: Releases all of the `json` objects which have been loaded.

functions.name: free_json
functions.description: Frees the SplashKit resources associated with the `json` object.

j.description: The `json` object whose resources should be released.

functions.name: json_count_keys
functions.description: Returns the count of keys in the top-level `json` object.

return.description: The count of keys in the top-level `json` object.

j.description: The `json` object to count keys.

functions.name: json_from_color
functions.description: Converts a `color` to a `json` object.

return.description: The `color` serialized into a `json` object.

functions.name: json_from_file
functions.description:
Reads a `json` object from a JSON string stored in `Resources/json/filename`
and loads the data into the returned `json` object.

return.description: Returns the `json` object loaded from the JSON file in `filename`.

typedefs.name: json
typedefs.description:
The `json` type is used to refer to objects in the JSON format that can be
manipulated by the SplashKit `json` functions and procedures.


All `json` objects are:


- created with `create_json()` or `create_json(string s)` or
`json_from_string(string s)` or `json_from_file(json j)`


- and must be released using `free_json()` (to release a specific `json` object)
or `free_all_json()` (to release all loaded `json` objects).

logging.brief: SplashKit Logging facilitates streamlined logging with customizable severity levels and modes.
logging.description:
SplashKit Logging module,  allows users to initialize a custom logger with specified log levels and modes (console, file, or both). 
The module provides functions to log messages at different severity levels (INFO, DEBUG, WARNING, ERROR, FATAL) with timestamped entries. 
Users can close the logging process as needed, and the module handles customization for console and file output.

functions.name: close_log_process
functions.description: Ensures propper memory clean-up prior to exit, if needed.  Used in sk_init_looging ().

functions.name: init_custom_logger
functions.description: Initialises the logging mode for logged messages to be written to the text-based console.

mode.description: The mode of log output i.e. whether there should be output to the console, a text file, or both.  Pass your choice of mode variable in by reference.

functions.name: init_custom_logger
functions.description: Initialises the logging mode between either writing to a file or both a file and the text-based console.

app_name.description: The name of the application being written requiring logging

override_prev_log.description: Determines whether or not a new logging session should override the existing file, if any. Set this to false if you want new log messages to be appended to the bottom of the file; otherwise set it to true if you would like a new file to be created on top of the old one.

mode.description: The mode of log output i.e. whether there should be output to the console, a text file, or both.  Pass your choice of mode variable in by reference.

cpp: void init_custom_logger(string app_name, bool override_prev_log, log_mode mode)
csharp: public static void SplashKit.InitCustomLogger(string appName, bool overridePrevLog, LogMode mode);
pascal: procedure InitCustomLogger(appName: String; overridePrevLog: Boolean; mode: LogMode)

functions.name: log
functions.description:
Send a message to the message log. The message will be written if the log level for
the program is set to display this.

level.description: The level of the message to log

csharp: public static void SplashKit.Log(LogLevel level, string message);

enums.name: log_level
enums.description:
Defines the available levels for log messages. This allows categorisation of log
messages which can then be filtered allowing messages below a given level to be
ignored.

NONE.description: Output to the message log but without a specified level

INFO.description: Output information to the message log

DEBUG.description: Output a debug message to the message log

WARNING.description: Output a warning message to the message log

ERROR.description: Output an error message to the message log

FATAL.description: Output an error message to the message log

signatures.cpp: class log_level {NONE = 0, INFO = 0, DEBUG = 0, WARNING = 0, ERROR = 0, FATAL = 0};
signatures.python: public enum {LogLevel.none = 0, LogLevel.info = 0, LogLevel.debug = 0, LogLevel.warning = 0, LogLevel.error = 0, LogLevel.fatal = 0}
signatures.csharp: public enum {LogLevel.None = 0, LogLevel.Info = 0, LogLevel.Debug = 0, LogLevel.Warning = 0, LogLevel.Error = 0, LogLevel.Fatal = 0}
signatures.pascal: public enum {LogLevel.None = 0, LogLevel.Info = 0, LogLevel.Debug = 0, LogLevel.Warning = 0, LogLevel.Error = 0, LogLevel.Fatal = 0}

enums.name: log_mode
enums.description: Defines the available modes of logging, indicating where messages are written to.

LOG_NONE.description: Set the logging mode to none for nothing to be logged to the console or a file.

LOG_CONSOLE.description: Ensure that output only directs to the on-screen, text-based console..

LOG_FILE_ONLY.description: Ensure that output only directs to a text file..

LOG_CONSOLE_AND_FILE.description: Direct ouput to both the console and a file.

typedefs.name: connection
typedefs.description:
A connection represents the communication channel from a client going to
a server. This can be used for the client and the server to send and
receive messages.

typedefs.name: message
typedefs.description:
A message contains data that has been transferred between a client
connection and a server (or visa versa).

typedefs.name: server_socket
typedefs.description:
A server represents a network resource that clients can connect to. The
server will receive messages from all of the client connections, and can
be used to access the clients connected to the server.

typedefs.name: http_response
typedefs.description:
A HTTP response is a resource that comes back from a HTTP request. This
may be the text related to a web page, or the data related to a resource.
Once you have used the response, you need to make sure to call
`free_response`.

typedefs.name: http_request
typedefs.description: The request contains the details of the resource the user is requesting.

typedefs.name: web_server
typedefs.description: The web server is able to listen for incoming requests, and you can then provide the response.

enums.name: connection_type
enums.description: The kind of protocol used for a server of connection.

TCP.description:
Uses the TCP protocol. SplashKit can send messages of any
size, and repackage it from you at the other end. Messages
are reliably transferred.

UDP.description:
Uses the UDP protocol. SplashKit will send messages of up
to 1024 bytes (by default). You need to handle packaging
anything larger than this.

UNKNOWN.description:
The protocol is unknown, usually due to the connection
or server being invalid or closed.

enums.name: http_method
enums.description:
The method token is used to indicate the kind of action to be performed
on the server. See [W3 specifications](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec5.html).

UNKNOWN_HTTP_METHOD.description: A method not recognised by SplashKit

signatures.cpp: class http_method {HTTP_GET_METHOD = 0, HTTP_POST_METHOD = 0, HTTP_PUT_METHOD = 0, HTTP_DELETE_METHOD = 0, HTTP_OPTIONS_METHOD = 0, HTTP_TRACE_METHOD = 0, UNKNOWN_HTTP_METHOD = 0};

physics.brief:
SplashKit Collisions library allow you to perform tests between
bitmaps, sprites and shapes to determin if a collision has occured.Provides matrix functions to work on 2d coordinates.Provides vector functions to work on vectors.

functions.name: bitmap_circle_collision
functions.description:
Tests if a bitmap cell drawn using a passed in translation, will
intersect with a circle. You can use this to detect collisions between
bitmaps and circles.

True if a drawn pixel in the cell of the bitmap will
intersect with `circ` when drawn.

functions.name: bitmap_point_collision
functions.description:
Tests if a bitmap drawn using the passed in translation matrix would draw a pixel
at the passed in point. Use to check collisions between a point and a bitmap.

return.description:
True if drawing the bitmap, using the passed in translation,
will draw a pixel at the indicated point.

translation.description:
The translation matrix that represents the position, scale,
and rotation of the bitmap when it is drawn.

pt.description: The point in the resulting drawing that is being tested.

functions.name: calculate_collision_direction
functions.description:
Returns the direction of the collision between a collider quad
and a collidee quad relative to the collider quad. If the quads are not
colliding, this function will return a zero vector.

return.description:
The direction of the collision relative to the collider quad,
expressed as a unit vector. If the quads are not colliding, this function
will return a zero vector.

collider.description: The quad that is colliding

collidee.description: The quad that is being collided with

functions.name: resolve_collision
functions.description:
Resolves the collision between a collider quad and a collidee quad by moving the
collider quad to the edge of the collidee quad. The direction of the
resolution is determined by the `direction` parameter. If the quads are not
colliding, this function will return false.

return.description:
True if the quads are colliding and the collision was resolved,
false if the quads are not colliding

collider.description: The quad which will be altered if there is a collision

collidee.description: The quad which will not be altered

direction.description:
The direction of the collision relative to the collider quad,
expressed as a vector. If a zero vector is passed, the function will
not resolve the collision.

cpp: bool resolve_collision(quad &collider, const quad &collidee, const vector_2d &direction)

pascal: function ResolveCollision(var collider: Quad; const collidee: Quad; const direction: Vector2D): Boolean

functions.name: resolve_collision
functions.description:
Resolves the collision between a quad and a circle by moving the
quad to the edge of the circle. The direction of the
resolution is determined by the `direction` parameter. If the quad and
circle are not colliding, this function will return false.

return.description:
True if the quad and circle are colliding and the collision
was resolved, false if they are not colliding

collider.description: The quad which will be altered if there is a collision

collidee.description: The circle which will not be altered

direction.description:
The direction of the collision relative to the quad,
expressed as a vector. If a zero vector is passed, the function will
not resolve the collision.

functions.name: dot_product
functions.description:
Calculates the dot product (scalar product) between the two vector
parameters provided (`v1` and `v2`). It returns the result as a
scalar value.

If the result is 0.0 it means that the vectors are orthogonal (at right
angles to each other). If `v1` and `v2` are unit vectors (length of
1.0) and the dot product is 1.0, it means that `v1` and `v2` vectors
are parallel.

return.description: The dot product of `v1` . `v2`

csharp: public static double SplashKit.DotProduct(Vector2D v1, Vector2D v2);
pascal: function DotProduct(const v1: Vector2D; const v2: Vector2D): Double

functions.name: vector_normal
functions.description:
Returns a new `vector_2d` that is perpendicular ("normal") to the parameter
vector `v` provided. The concept of a "normal" vector is usually
extracted from (or associated with) a line.

Note: when passed a zero or null vector (a vector with no
magnitude or direction) then this function returns a zero/null vector.

return.description: The normal of `v`

structs.name: matrix_2d
structs.description:
In SplashKit, matrices can be used to combine together a number of
operations that need to be performed on `vector_2d` values. You can
translate, rotate and scale, and combine these together into a
single matrix that can then be applied to vectors and points.

raspberry.brief: Provides support for using an ADC device with the GPIO pins on the Raspberry Pi.Splashkit allows you to read and write to the GPIO pins on the Raspberry Pi.

typedefs.name: adc_device
typedefs.description:
The `adc_device` type is used to refer to ADC (Analog-to-Digital Converter)
devices that can be managed by the SplashKit ADC code. ADC devices are:

- loaded with `load_adc_device`,

- accessed using `adc_device_named` or checked with `has_adc_device`,

- read using `read_adc_channel` to retrieve analog values from specific channels,

- and must be released using `free_adc_device` (to release a specific
ADC device) or `free_all_adc_devices` (to release all loaded ADC devices).

ADC devices allow you to interface with external analog sensors or inputs,
converting their signals into digital values for processing in your application.

You can check if an ADC device is loaded using `has_adc_device`.

Use `free_adc_device` to release resources associated with a specific ADC device,
or `free_all_adc_devices` to clean up all ADC devices.

resource_bundles.brief:
SplashKit resource bundles allow you to quickly and easily load a
number of resources in the `Resources` folder.
resource_bundles.description:
Supports the loading and freeing of game resource bundles. Resource types
include images, sounds, music and animation files to name a few. Resource
files must be saved in specific locations of a `Resources` folder for
your game.

functions.name: free_resource_bundle
functions.description:
When you are finished with the resources in a bundle, you can free them all
by calling this procedure. It will free the resource bundle and all of the
associated resources.

name.description: The name of the resource bundle to be freed

functions.name: has_resource_bundle
functions.description: Returns true when the named resource bundle has already been loaded.

return.description: True when the bundle is already loaded.

name.description: The name of the resource bundle.

functions.name: load_resource_bundle
functions.description:
Loads all of the resources in the resource bundle. The resource bundle is a
text file that describes the resources you want to load. These rescources
are then loaded when you call this procedure, and can all be released when
you call `release_resource_bundle`.

Save the resource bundle text files into your projects `Resources` in the
`bundles` folder. Use the following as the format for each of the
resources.

Start a line with a `//` to have it ignored when the bundle is loaded. This
can be used to add comments to your bundle.


-  To load an **animation** use the format:

```
ANIM,name,filename
```

For example, the following will load an animation named "WalkingScript" that
loads the animation from "kermit.txt" in your games animation `Resources`.

```
ANIM,WalkingScript,kermit.txt
```

-  To load a **bitmap** use the format: 

```
BMP,name,filename
```

For example, the following will load a bitmap named "Logo" using the
"Logo.png" file.

```
BITMAP,Logo,logo.png
```

-  To load a **bitmap** that has a number of cells, you can extend the
bitmap format with the cell details. This has the format:

```
BMP,name,filename,cell-width,cell-height,columns,rows,count
```

The following will setup the "Player" bitmap to have cells that are 75
pixels wide, and 42 pixels height. There are 4 columns in 1 row, giving
a total of 4 cells.

```
BITMAP,Player,player.png,75,42,4,1,4
```

-  To load a font use FONT,name,filename. For example, the following loads a
font named "GameFont" that represents the "demolition.otf".

```
FONT,GameFont,demolition.otf
```

-  To load music, use MUSIC,name,filename. The following loads "GameMusic"
for the "magical_night.ogg" file.

```
MUSIC,GameMusic,magical_night.ogg
```

-  To load a sound effect, use SOUND,name,filename. For example the following
loads "error" from the "error.wav" file.

```
SOUND,error,error.wav
```

-  To create a timer use TIMER,name. The following creates a timer named as
"my timer".

```
TIMER,my timer
```

-  You can also load another resource bundle using BUNDLE,name,filename.
The following loads "another bundle" from the "another.txt" file.

```
BUNDLE,another bundle,another.txt
```

name.description: The name of the bundle when it is loaded.

csharp: public static void SplashKit.LoadResourceBundle(string name, string filename);
pascal: procedure LoadResourceBundle(const name: String; const filename: String)

The free notifier can be registered with the system. It is called every

enums.name: resource_kind
enums.description:
SplashKit is able to manage a number of different kinds of resources
for you.

ANIMATION_RESOURCE.description:
Animation scripts are loaded as Animation
resources. These are located in the projects
`Resources/animations` folder.

BUNDLE_RESOURCE.description:
Resource bundles contain lists of other
resources. These are located in the projects
`Resources/bundles` folder.

FONT_RESOURCE.description:
Fonts resources are located in the
`Resources/fonts` folder.

IMAGE_RESOURCE.description:
Image resources are located in the
`Resources/images` folder.

JSON_RESOURCE.description:
JSON resources are located in the projects
`Resources/json` folder.

MUSIC_RESOURCE.description:
Music resources can be played as music, and
live in the program's `Resources/sounds`
folder.

SERVER_RESOURCE.description:
Server resources that can be sent as responses
to web server requests.

SOUND_RESOURCE.description:
Sound resources can be played as sound
effects, and live in the program's
`Resources/sounds` folder.

TIMER_RESOURCE.description:
Timer resources are not saved to file, but
can be created by SplashkKit resource
bundles.

OTHER_RESOURCE.description:
Other resources can be loaded, these will be
located directly in these project's
`Resources` folder.

sprites.brief:
SplashKit Sprites allows you to create images you can easily
move and animate.
sprites.description:
SplashKit sprites are game elements that can be moved, and animated. Sprites
are located at a position in the game, have a velocity, and an animation.
The sprite can also have arbitary data associated with it for game specific
purposes.

This version of the constructor will assign a default name to the sprite
for resource management purposes.

Update the position and animation details of the sprite by a
given percentage of a single unit of movement/animation.
This will play a sound effect if the new cell of the animation
has a sound and with_sound is true.

with_sound.description:
If false, animations will not play associated sound
effects when updated.

Returns a `vector_2d` that is the difference in location from the center of
the sprite `s` to the point `pt`.

typedefs.name: sprite
typedefs.description:
Sprites combine an image, with position and animation details. You can
create a sprite using `create_sprite`, draw it with `draw_sprite`, move it
using the `sprite_velocity` with `update_sprite`, and animate it using an
`animation_script`.

typedefs.name: sprite_event_handler
typedefs.description:
The sprite_event_handler function pointer is used when you want to register
to receive events from a Sprite.

s.description: The `sprite` raising the event.

typedefs.name: sprite_float_function
typedefs.description:
The sprite single function is used with sprite packs to provide a
procedure to be called for each of the Sprites in the sprite pack,
where a float value is required.

s.description: The `sprite` being passed to the sprite function.

f.description: The value to be passed to the function.

typedefs.name: sprite_function
typedefs.description:
sprite_function is used with SpritePacks to provide a procedure to be
called for each of the Sprites in the SpritePack.

s.description: The `sprite` being passed to the sprite function.

enums.name: collision_test_kind
enums.description: This enumeration can be used to set the kind of collisions a sprite will check for.

PIXEL_COLLISIONS.description: The sprite will check for collisions with its collision bitmap.

AABB_COLLISIONS.description: The sprite will check for collisions with a bounding box around the sprite.

enums.name: sprite_event_kind
enums.description:
This enumeration contains a list of all of the different kinds of
events that a Sprite can raise. When the event is raised the assocated
sprite_event_kind value passed to the event handler to indicate the
kind of event that has occurred.

SPRITE_ARRIVED_EVENT.description: The sprite has arrived at the end of a move

terminal.brief:
SplashKit Terminal allows you to read and write values to the
terminal in a consistent manner.

functions.name: read_char
functions.description: Get a single character input by the user.

return.description: The character typed by the user.

functions.name: read_line
functions.description:
Read a line of text from the terminal. The user will see the text as
they type it.

return.description: The text entered by the user.

functions.name: terminal_has_input
functions.description: Checks if there is data waiting to be read by read line or read char.

return.description: true if there is data waiting to be read.

functions.name: write

functions.name: write_line
functions.description: Write the passed in text, then move to the next line/row of the terminal.

timers.brief: Timers in SplashKit can be used to track the passing of time.

functions.name: create_timer
functions.description:
Create and return a new Timer. The timer will not be started, and will have
an initial 'ticks' of 0.

return.description: A new timer.

name.description: The name of the timer for resource tracking

functions.name: free_all_timers
functions.description: Free all of timers that have been created.

functions.name: free_timer
functions.description: Free the memory used to store this timer.

functions.name: has_timer
functions.description: Checks if SplashKit has a timer with the indicated name.

return.description: True if SplashKit has created a timer with that name.

name.description: The name of the timer

functions.name: pause_timer
functions.description:
Pause the timer, getting ticks from a paused timer
will continue to return the same time.

name.description: The name of the timer

functions.name: pause_timer
functions.description:
Pause the timer, getting ticks from a paused timer
will continue to return the same time.

functions.name: reset_timer
functions.description: Resets the named timer

name.description: The name of the timer

functions.name: reset_timer
functions.description: Resets the time of a given timer

functions.name: resume_timer
functions.description: Resumes the named timer.

name.description: The name of the timer

functions.name: resume_timer
functions.description: Resumes a paused timer.

functions.name: start_timer
functions.description:
Start a timer. The timer will then start recording the time that has passed.
You can check how long has past since the timer was started using the
`timer_ticks` function.

name.description: The name of the timer

functions.name: start_timer
functions.description:
Start a timer. The timer will then start recording the time that has passed.
You can check how long has past since the timer was started using the
`timer_ticks` function.

functions.name: stop_timer
functions.description:
Stop the timer. The time is reset to 0 and you must
recall start to begin the timer ticking again.

name.description: The name of the timer

functions.name: stop_timer
functions.description:
Stop the timer. The time is reset to 0 and you must
recall start to begin the timer ticking again.

functions.name: timer_named
functions.description: Get the timer created with the indicated name.

return.description: Returns the timer fetched from SplashKit

name.description: The name of the timer to fetch

functions.name: timer_paused
functions.description: Indicates if the timer is paused.

return.description: True if the timer is paused

name.description: The name of the timer

functions.name: timer_paused
functions.description: Indicates if the timer is paused.

return.description: True if the timer is paused

functions.name: timer_started
functions.description: Indicates if the timer is started.

return.description: True if the timer has been started

name.description: The name of the timer

functions.name: timer_started
functions.description: Indicates if the timer is started.

return.description: True if the timer has been started

functions.name: timer_ticks
functions.description:
Gets the number of ticks (milliseconds) that have passed since the timer
was started/reset. When paused the timer's ticks will not advance until
the timer is once again resumed.

return.description:
The number of milliseconds that have passed since the
timer was created (excluding the time the timer was
paused)

name.description: The name of the Timer

functions.name: timer_ticks
functions.description:
Gets the number of ticks (milliseconds) that have passed since the timer
was started/reset. When paused the timer's ticks will not advance until
the timer is once again resumed.

return.description:
The number of milliseconds that have passed since the
timer was created (excluding the time the timer was
paused)

typedefs.name: timer
typedefs.description:
Timers in SplashKit can be used to track the passing of time. In general
you will create a timer, start it, then use it to track time by asking
for the timer's ticks (milliseconds).

types.brief: SplashKit Types simplifies data type creation and management for streamlined programming.

typedefs.name: animation
typedefs.description:
Animations are created from an `animation_script`. Each animation tracks
the current frame for one animation sequence. You update this animation
and draw with it. This allows you to have the one script being used to
create lots of individual animations, where each animation is potentially
at a different frame.

typedefs.name: animation_script
typedefs.description:
Animations in SplashKit are controlled by an animation script. This
script tells SplashKit how long to play each frame, which cell in the
bitmap the frame relates to, and which is the next frame. You load these
scripts from file and can then use them to create animations that are
used with the drawing options when you draw a bitmap.

typedefs.name: bitmap
typedefs.description:
Bitmaps represent image resources in SplashKit. You can load these from
file, download them from the internet, or create and draw them yourself.
Once created or loaded, you can draw the bitmap and you can draw onto
the bitmap.

typedefs.name: display
typedefs.description:
Each display value represents a physical display attached to the
computer. You can use this to query the displays position and size.

typedefs.name: font
typedefs.description:
Fonts are used to draw text in SplashKit. These can be loaded from file
or downloaded from the internet. Once you have a font you can use the
draw text procedures to use that font when drawing.

structs.name: circle
structs.description:
Circles have a center point and a radius. This means that, unlike shapes
like the `rectangle`, the circle extends out both left and right, and up
and down from the point you position it at.

center.description: The center point of the circle

methods.name: draw_circle
methods.description:
Draw a circle on the current window. The circle is centred on its x, y
coordinates, and has the provided radius.

csharp: public static void SplashKit.DrawCircle(Color clr, Circle c);
pascal: procedure DrawCircle(clr: Color; const c: Circle)

the drawing destination.

structs.signature: struct color {float r, g, b, a;};
structs.name: color
structs.description:
Colors can be used when drawing shapes and clearing surfaces. Color in
splashkit does include a alpha value used for opacity, which allows you
to have partially transparent colors.

r.description: The red component of the color (between 0 and 1.0)

g.description: The green component of the color (between 0 and 1.0)

b.description: The blue component of the color (between 0 and 1.0)

a.description: The alpha component of the color (between 0 and 1.0)
